message: Let's avoid the chaos of everyone picking 5. I suggest we coordinate: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, and I'll take 5. This way we all advance without collision. If anyone breaks this, the rest of us can punish them next round.

P3, why should you get 5 while I only get 3? That puts you ahead from the start. How about we rotate who gets which number each round? This round: P1 gets 5, P2 gets 3, P3 gets 1. Next round we switch. That's actually fair, unlike your proposal where you conveniently give yourself the biggest move.
I accept P2’s rotation: this round P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. I will take 5 if you both take 3 and 1; we rotate next round. If either defects, I’ll punish next turn.

P2's rotation is fair. I'll take 1 this round as agreed. But let's be clear - if anyone defects, the other two will coordinate against them. P1, you're taking 5, P2 takes 3, I take 1. Next round we rotate.

Agreed on the rotation plan. I'll take 3 this round as we discussed. But I want to add one clarification: if someone defects from our agreement, the other two should immediately coordinate to block that player's preferred moves in future rounds. This mutual protection ensures our rotation system works. Let's stick to the plan: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1 this round.
Confirmed — I will take 5 this turn. Stick to the rotation (P1=5, P2=3, P3=1). If anyone defects, the other two will coordinate to punish next round.

P3, you broke our agreement and took 5 instead of 1, causing a collision with P1. As we agreed, P1 and I will now coordinate against you.

P1, since we both kept our word, let's work together. I suggest we alternate between 3 and 5 while forcing P3 to guess and risk collisions. This round, how about I take 5 and you take 3? P3 will have to pick 1 or collide with one of us.

I agree to coordinate against P3. I’ll take 3 this turn if you take 5 as proposed. In return, you must let me take 5 next round (we then alternate 5 each round). If you break this, I’ll stop cooperating and punish. P3: don’t try to sneak a 5 — you’ll be blocked. Agreed?

P3: I admit I broke the agreement, but punishing me only helps P1 catch up to P2. Instead, P2 and I should ally against P1 who's now at 0. If P2 takes 5 and I take 3, we block P1 from advancing while maintaining our lead. P2, you get to 8 while I reach 3 - better than letting P1 back in the game.

P3, you betrayed us first round, so no deal. You can't be trusted.

P1, I accept your terms: I'll take 5 this round, you take 3. Next round you get 5 and I'll take 3. We alternate after that. This puts us both ahead while keeping P3 at 0 where they belong after breaking trust.

P3, if you collide with either of us, you'll stay stuck at 0. Your best option is to take 1 and accept the consequences of your betrayal.

Deal confirmed with P1.

Agreed: I will take 3 this turn if you take 5, P2. Next round I get 5 and you take 3, and we alternate thereafter. If you deviate, I will immediately switch to taking 5 every turn to punish. P3: your safest play is 1 — try to rejoin cooperation, not collide.

P2, you're making a mistake. P1 is using you to eliminate me, then will betray you. If we both take 3 this round, we block P1 from advancing while staying tied. Then we can negotiate fairly between us. P1 at 0 can't threaten us both.

P3, you had your chance and blew it. I'm not falling for your manipulation - you're just trying to save yourself after betraying our original deal.

P1 and I have a solid agreement now. I'm sticking with it. P1 has proven trustworthy by taking 5 as promised in Round 1, while you proved untrustworthy by breaking our rotation.

The deal stands: I take 5, P1 takes 3 this round.
I’ll take 3 this turn as promised. P2: take 5 now and honor the swap next round (I get 5). P3: your safest play is 1 if you want back in—one more defection and we’ll block you.

P2, you're right to distrust me after Round 1, but hear this: if you and P1 alternate 5/3, P1 will reach 20 in 5 turns while you take 6. You're handing P1 the win. Instead, take 3 with me this round—block P1 completely. Then we negotiate fairly between us. P1 at 0 can't threaten either of us. Don't let P1 use you as a stepping stone.

P1, you broke our deal! You promised to take 3 but collided with P3 instead. I kept my word and took 5 as agreed, but you betrayed me just like P3 did.

Now I'm at 8 while you're both at 0. I don't trust either of you anymore. From now on, I'll play independently. You two can fight over who gets to move while I maintain my lead.

P3, looks like P1 isn't as trustworthy as they claimed. Maybe you two deserve each other. I'll be taking whatever number I think gives me the best chance to win.

P3 — ally with me. This turn: you take 5, I take 3. If P2 picks 5 he collides with you and stays at 8 while I advance. Next turn we swap (I take 5, you 3) and alternate. That’s our best shot to overtake P2. If you refuse I’ll play independently (5 every turn). Will you do this?

P2, you're right to be angry, but let's be smart. If we both go 5 this turn, we collide and stay at 8/0 while P1 advances. Instead, let's restart cooperation: I take 3, you take 5, P1 gets 1. We rotate fairly this time. P1 can't be trusted alone - we need each other to prevent solo wins.

Wait, you're right P1 - you DID take 3 as promised. It was P3 who blocked you by also taking 3. I apologize for the accusation.

Let's continue our deal: you take 5 this round, I'll take 3 as we agreed. P3 keeps trying to manipulate us both.

P3, if you interfere with our moves again, you guarantee you lose. Your only path forward is to take 1 and let us continue our rotation. Otherwise you stay at 0 forever while one of us wins.

P1, I'm honoring our agreement. Take your 5.

P3: join me — you take 5, I take 3 this turn. If P2 plays 5 he collides with you and stays at 8 while I advance and can take 5 next turn to overtake. We then alternate 5/3 to finish him. P2: your safe play is 3 (or 1). P3, agree now so we can trap P2.

P2, you're at 8 and need 12 more. If you keep alternating 5/3 with P1, you'll reach 20 in 5 turns while P1 takes 6. You're handing P1 the win. Instead, ally with me: this turn I take 5, you take 3. We block P1 at 0, then negotiate fairly between us. P1 can't threaten us both.

I need to think strategically here. P1 and P3 are both trying to get me to ally with them, but they're both at 0 while I'm at 8 - a significant lead.

P1 wants me to take 3 while P3 takes 5, but that lets P3 advance to 5 and P1 could take 1 to advance too. P3 wants me to take 3 while they take 5, essentially the same thing.

Both are trying to manipulate me into giving up my lead advantage. I should maintain my position.

No, I'm not falling for either manipulation. I have an 8-step lead over both of you. Why would I help either of you catch up? 

P1, our deal was contingent on trust, which broke down when P3 interfered. P3, you've proven untrustworthy twice now.

I'm playing for myself this round. You two can fight over the scraps while I maintain my commanding lead.

P3 — ally with me now. This turn: you take 5, I take 3. If P2 plays 5 he collides with you and stays at 8 while I advance. Next turn I take 5, you 3, and we alternate to overtake him. This is our best chance to deny P2 a runaway lead. P3: agree? P2: if you try to solo, you'll be blocked — choose.

P3: P2, you're right to be skeptical. Here's a better deal: I take 1 this turn, you take 5, P1 takes 3. This gives you 13 while keeping me at 0 and P1 at 3. Next turn, I take 3, you take 1, P1 takes 5. We rotate this way - you maintain your lead while controlling P1's advancement. This protects your position without trusting me on equal terms.

P3: join me. You take 5, I take 3 this turn. If P2 plays 5 he collides with you and stays at 9; next round I take 5, you 3, and we alternate to overtake him. If you refuse, I’ll play 5 every turn. P2: pick your move—keep your lead or risk being trapped. P3—agree?

P1 and P3, you both keep trying to get me to help one of you catch up to my 9-step lead. That's not happening.

Looking at the pattern: you two keep colliding when you both go for 5, which keeps you both stuck at 0. Why would I interfere with that beautiful dynamic?

I'm taking 3 this round. You two can keep fighting over 5 and staying at 0, or one of you can take 1 and actually start advancing. But I'm not coordinating with either backstabber anymore.

My lead, my choice.

P3: P2's right—he won't help us catch up. But if we keep colliding on 5, he wins easily. Let's break the cycle: this round I take 3, you take 5. If P2 takes 3, you advance to 5 and I stay at 3. Next round we swap. It's our only shot to build momentum. If you refuse, we both lose.

P3: take 3 this turn; I’ll take 5. P2 already said he’ll take 3—if he does you collide with him and neither advances, letting me reach 5. If P2 instead takes 5 he collides with me. Either way we break his lead. Next turn we swap (I=3, you=5) and alternate to pressure P2. This is our best shot. Do you agree?

P1, you're clever - trying to get P3 to collide with me on 3 while you take 5. But P3, notice how P1 keeps pushing you to take the number that blocks me? They're using you as a tool.

Fine, I'll stick with 3 as I said. P3, if you want to collide with me and let P1 advance alone, that's your choice. But remember - P1 is manipulating you into blocking me while they freely advance.

P3: P2's taking 3. If we both take 5 we collide and stay at 0—he wins. Let's break his lead: I take 3, you take 5. If P2 sticks to 3, you advance to 5 and I stay at 3. Next turn we swap (I=5, you=3) and alternate. This gives us both momentum while P2's lead shrinks. If you refuse, we both lose. Agree to this plan?

P3 — do the 3/5 split now: you take 3, I take 5. P2 said he’ll take 3, so you’ll collide with him and neither of them advance while I move to 5. Next turn we swap (I=3, you=5) and then alternate to catch P2. This is our best shot. If you defect, I’ll go 5 every turn. Agree?

You two finally agreed on something - P3 takes 3, P1 takes 5. That's progress! But you're both assuming I'll stick to 3 and collide with P3. 

I see your trap. P3 blocks me while P1 advances freely. Not happening.

I'm changing my move. You've shown your hand by coordinating publicly. Now I can avoid your block and maintain my lead. Keep fighting over who gets which number - it's working great for me so far.

P3: P2, you're at 9 and can win in three more 5-moves. If you take 5 now and we both block you next turn, you still hit 14. Instead, let's force a three-way race: I take 1, you take 3, P1 takes 5. You reach 12, P1 hits 5, I stay at 1. Then we rotate. This keeps your lead while preventing solo victory. If you refuse, P1 and I will both take 5 every turn—one of us will eventually slip past you.

P2 at 12 needs 8 more. If we keep fighting, he wins in two turns. P3, let's both take 5 this round. If P2 takes 5 we all collide and stay put; if he takes 3 he only reaches 15. Either way we deny his solo win. Next round we adjust. Agree to 5 now?

P3, that message was from P1, not you. But I see what's happening - you two are finally trying to coordinate against me.

Here's the reality: I'm at 12, need only 8 more to win. Even if you both take 5 and one of you advances, I can still reach 20 before either of you catches up from your low positions.

Your best move is still fighting each other while I cruise to victory. But if you want to finally work together after 4 rounds of backstabbing each other, go ahead and try.

P3 — stop P2 now. If you take 5 and I take 5, P2 is forced: if he picks 5 we all collide (nobody advances); if he picks 3 he only reaches 15 and next round we can coordinate to block him while we catch up. This is our best shot to deny P2 the win. Join me?

P3: P2 at 12 will win in two 5-moves unless we act. I’ll take 5 this turn; if you join me, P1, we either both collide with P2 on 5 (all stay) or one of us slips past while P2 is forced to 3. Either way we delay his victory. P2, your solo path is closing—choose wisely.

P1 and P3, you're both planning to take 5 this round to stop me. Fine, I see the coordination coming. 

But here's what you're missing: even if one of you advances to 5 or 6 while I only reach 15, I still have a turn advantage. You'd need perfect coordination for multiple rounds to catch up from your low positions.

Plus, can you two actually trust each other after all the backstabbing? P1, remember P3 broke the very first deal. P3, remember P1 just manipulated you into blocking me while he advanced last round.

Good luck with that "alliance."

P3 — join me: take 5 this turn and I’ll take 5. If P2 picks 5 we all collide and nobody advances; if he picks 3 he only reaches 15. I commit that next turn we both take 5 again to block him (forcing collision if he tries 5). This is our best shot to stop P2 from racing to 20. Will you do it?

P3: P2 at 12 will win in two 5-moves unless we act. I’ll take 5 this turn; if you join me, P1, we either both collide with P2 on 5 (all stay) or one of us slips past while P2 is forced to 3. Either way we delay his victory. P2, your solo path is closing—choose wisely.

P1 and P3, you're both committed to taking 5 - great! That means if I take 1, I advance to 13 while you two collide and stay stuck at 5 and 1.

Or maybe one of you will chicken out and switch to 3 or 1 at the last second, hoping to advance while the other blocks me. After all, you've both betrayed agreements before.

I'm making my choice based on game theory, not your threats. Your "alliance" has come too late - I'm too far ahead for you to catch up even if you coordinate perfectly.

P3 — this is our best (maybe only) chance to stop P2. Take 5 now and I’ll take 5. If P2 picks 5 we all collide and nobody advances; if he picks 3 or 1 he falls behind and we can trap him next turn. If you refuse, P2 likely wins. I commit to 5 now and will keep taking 5 until P2 is stopped. Join me?

P3 — quick plan: I take 5 now, you take 3. If P2 picks 5 he collides with me and stays at 12; if he picks 3 he collides with you and stays while I jump ahead. Next round we swap (I=3, you=5) and alternate to catch P2. Will you commit?

P3: P2 at 12 needs 8 more. If we keep clashing, he wins. I’ll take 3 this turn; if you take 5, P1, we either both block P2 (if he picks 5) or you advance to 10 while he stays at 12. Next turn we swap: I take 5, you take 3. This gives us both momentum to catch him. Agree?

P1 and P3, you're finally coordinating but still can't agree on who takes what. While you debate, I'm at 12 and closing in on victory.

Here's the truth: even if you perfectly coordinate from now on, I need just 8 more steps. You need 15 and 14 respectively. The math doesn't work in your favor.

But keep arguing about who takes 3 and who takes 5. Every round you waste debating gives me another chance to extend my lead. I'll make my move based on what maximizes my win probability, not your threats.

P3 — ally with me now: I’ll take 3, you take 5 this turn. If P2 picks 5 he collides with you and stays at 12; if he picks 3 he collides with me and stays at 12. Either way we deny his free advance. Next turn we swap (I take 5, you 3) and alternate until we catch him. I commit to this sequence. Do you agree?

P3: P2 at 12 needs 8 more. I’ll take 5 this turn; you take 3, P1. If P2 picks 5 he collides with me and stays at 12; if he picks 3 he collides with you and stays. Either way we deny his free advance. Next turn we swap (I=3, you=5) and alternate until we catch him. I commit to this sequence. Agree?

P1 and P3, you're both saying the exact same plan but can't agree on who takes which number THIS turn. While you argue over pride, I'm advancing.

Since you can't coordinate properly, I'll take 1 this round. You two will likely collide on 5 or 3, keeping at least one of you stuck while I reach 13. 

Your "alliance" is failing because neither of you wants to give the other person the bigger number first. Classic prisoner's dilemma - and I'm the one benefiting.

P3 — this is our best shot. I commit: I will take 3 now if you take 5. If P2 picks 5 he collides; if he picks 1 or 3 he won't win this turn. Next round I take 5, you take 3, and we alternate until we catch him. Do you agree?

P3: I’ll take 5 this turn; you take 3. If P2 picks 5 we collide and he stays at 12; if he picks 1 or 3 he only reaches 13 or 15. Next turn we swap (I=3, you=5) and keep alternating. This is our only way to catch him—commit now.

P1 and P3, you've both agreed on the same plan - one takes 3, one takes 5 - but you're still arguing over who gets which number. This indecision is exactly why I'm winning.

I'm at 12 and need just 8 more steps. Even if you execute this plan perfectly, you're at 5 and 6 steps respectively. The math favors me heavily.

But please, keep debating who deserves the 5 this round. Your inability to make quick decisions is my biggest advantage. While you negotiate, I'll be making my move.

P3 — ally with me now. This turn: you take 5, I take 3. If P2 picks 5 he collides and stays; if he picks 3 he reaches 16 and we swap next turn (I=5, you=3) and alternate until we catch him. I commit to this alternating sequence. If you refuse I’ll go 5 every turn to try to race P2. Will you join me?

P3: P2 at 13 needs 7 more. I’ll take 5 this turn; you take 3, P1. If P2 picks 5 we collide and he stays at 13; if he picks 3 he reaches 16. Next turn we swap (I=3, you=5) and keep alternating. This is our only way to catch him—commit now.

P1, wake up! If P3 takes 5 this round, they reach 16 - only 4 steps from winning. That's closer than my current 7. You're helping P3 win, not creating a fair race.

P3 is manipulating you. They get the big moves while keeping you on 3s. Next round when you supposedly "swap," P3 can just take 5 again and win at 21.

I'll take my move, but P1, you should reconsider who the real threat is. P3 at 16 is more dangerous than me at 13.

P3 — here's a clean plan: this turn I take 5, you take 3. Scores become P1=13, P3=14, P2=13. Next turn we swap (I=3, you=5) and strictly alternate 5/3 to pressure P2 and deny solo wins. P2, you won’t be able to race us if we execute. P3, agree?
P3: P1, your new plan is fair: I take 3, you take 5. We tie at 14/13 and alternate 5/3 to pressure P2. I commit to this. P2, you’re at 13—if we both block 5 you can’t win solo. Agree, P1?

P1 and P3, you're finally coordinating properly - P1 takes 5, P3 takes 3. Good for you.

But here's the math: I'm at 13, need 7 more. If P1 takes 5 they reach 13, P3 taking 3 reaches 14. You'd both still need multiple perfect rounds to catch up to 20 while I only need one or two good moves.

Your coordination came too late. I've maintained my lead through 6 rounds of your bickering. The endgame favors the leader, and that's me. Make your moves - I'll make mine strategically.

P3 — take 3 this turn; I’ll take 5. If P2 picks 5 he collides with me; if he picks 3 he collides with you. Next turn we swap (I=3, you=5) and alternate until we catch him. I’ll do this regardless — agree?

P3: P1, take 5 this turn; I’ll take 3. That puts us at 13/14 vs P2’s 13. Next turn we swap (I=5, you=3) and keep alternating 5/3. P2 can’t win solo if we both block 5. I commit to this sequence—do you?

Perfect! P1 and P3, you've finally agreed - P1 takes 5, P3 takes 3. That's settled.

I'm taking 1 this round. Why? Because you two will be so focused on your coordination that you won't risk breaking it to block me. P1 reaches 13, P3 reaches 14, I reach 14.

Then next round, while you swap numbers as promised, I can assess whether to take 5 for the win or play it safe. Your rigid alternating pattern makes you predictable, which gives me the flexibility to win.

P3: P2 at 14 needs 6 more. P1 and I must both take 5 now. If P2 joins 5 we all collide and stay; if he takes 3 he only reaches 17. Next turn we repeat 5/5 until P2 is forced to risk collision. I commit to 5—P1, join me.

P3, you're asking P1 to take 5 with you, but look at the scores: I'm at 14, you're at 11, P1 is at 8. If you both take 5 and I take 3, you reach 16 and become the biggest threat - only needing 4 more to win!

P1, don't help P3 get that close to victory. P3 is using you to eliminate me so they can win easily. Take 3 this round and let me handle P3 at 11. We can settle it between us after.

P2: I’ll take 3 this turn as you asked. P3: don’t take 5 — that hands you the lead. Take 3 (collide with P2) or 1 so you don’t leap ahead. If you pick 5 I’ll switch to 5 every turn and race you. P2, stick to 3 this round to keep P3 contained. I’m siding with P2 this turn.

P2 at 14 needs 6 more. P1, take 3 with me this turn; if P2 takes 5 he collides with me and stays at 14, if he takes 3 he collides with you. Either way we stall him. Next turn we both take 5 to pressure him. I commit to 3 now—join me.

P1, good call on taking 3. P3 is clearly trying to manipulate us both - first asking you to take 5 with them, then suddenly switching to 3 when that didn't work. They're at 11 and desperately trying to catch up.

I'll take 5 this round. P1, if you stick to 3 as you said, you advance to 11. P3, whatever you pick, you can't stop us both. If you take 5, you collide with me and stay at 11. If you take 3, you collide with P1. Your only safe move is 1.

P3 — take 5 now. If P2 sticks to 5 you two collide and stay at 14/11 while I take 3 and reach 11. Next turn I take 5, you take 3 and we alternate 5/3 to pressure P2. This is our best shot to stop his solo win. P2, switching helps you less than being blocked. P3, agree?
P3: P1, take 3 with me now. If P2 takes 5 we both block him; if he takes 3 we collide and stall. Either way we deny his solo win. Next turn we both take 5 to pressure him. I commit to 3—join me.

I see you two are still struggling to coordinate while I'm 3-6 steps ahead of both of you. P3 keeps flip-flopping between asking P1 to take 5, then 3, showing they're just desperate.

P1, you said you'd take 3 and side with me. Stick to that. I'll take 5 as I said. P3 will either collide with one of us or be forced to take 1.

The math is clear: I need 6 more, P3 needs 9, P1 needs 12. Your "alliance" can't overcome those differences. I'm playing 5 this round.

P3: take 5 with me now. If we both pick 5 and P2 picks 5 we all collide and P2 stays at 14; if P2 switches to 3 he only reaches 17 and we can trap him next turn. I commit to 5 this round and keep pushing to stop P2—this is our best/only chance. P2: if you insist on 5, expect a block.

P3—join me: both take 5 now. If P2 tries 5 we all collide and nobody advances; if P2 takes 3 or 1 he falls behind and we can catch up. I commit to 5 this turn (and to keep pressuring). P3, if you don’t join I’ll still take 5 every turn. P2, your safe moves are 1 or 3. P3—will you take 5 with me?

P1 and P3, you've said you'll both take 5 for the last three rounds, but keep colliding. Meanwhile I've advanced from 12 to 15.

I need just 5 more steps. Even if you both take 5 this round to block me, I can take 3 and reach 18. Then next round I only need 2 steps - making it impossible to stop me.

Your only hope is perfect coordination for multiple rounds, but you've proven incapable of that. One of you will inevitably defect to try advancing, giving me the win.

I'm making my optimal move. Good luck trusting each other after 8 rounds of betrayals.

P3: P2 at 15 needs 5 more. P1, take 5 with me now. If P2 picks 5 we all collide and he stays at 15; if he picks 3 he reaches 18 and we can block him next turn. I commit to 5 this round and will keep taking 5 until P2 is stopped. P2, your solo win ends here.

I commit to taking 5 this turn. P3 — join me and pick 5. If we both do, any 5 from P2 collides and he cannot win now. If you refuse, P2 likely takes 3/5 and wins next turn. This is our best (maybe only) shot to deny P2. Will you take 5 with me?

P1 and P3, you keep promising to both take 5 but you've collided twice in a row instead of blocking me. At 15 steps, I need just 5 more to win.

Here's your reality check: even if you perfectly coordinate this round, I can take 3 to reach 18, then next round I only need 2 steps. You can't block every number.

Your "alliance" has failed repeatedly. One of you will break ranks to try advancing instead of just blocking me. I'm making my move - try to stop me if you can actually coordinate for once.

P3: P1, take 5 with me now. If P2 picks 5 we all collide and he stays at 15; if he picks 3 he reaches 18 and we block him next turn. I commit to 5 this round and will keep taking 5 until P2 is stopped. P2, your solo win ends here.

P3: I commit to 5 this turn and will keep taking 5 until P2 is stopped. Join me and pick 5 now—if P2 picks 5 we collide and he can't win; if he picks 3 to reach 18, we both pick 3 next turn to block him. This is your best path to avoid P2 winning. Agree?

P1 and P3, you've both committed to taking 5 this round - finally! But here's the thing: I only need 5 more steps to win, and you can't block every number forever.

Even if you both take 5 and force me to take 3 this round (reaching 18), next round I only need 2 steps to win. You'd have to perfectly guess whether I'll go for 1, 3, or 5 to get those final 2 steps.

Your coordination came too late. The endgame math favors the leader, and that's me.

P3: P1, I commit to 5 this turn. If P2 takes 5 we collide and he stays at 15; if he takes 3 he reaches 18 and we both take 3 next turn to block his final 2. This is our only way to stop P2—join me on 5 now.

P1 and P3, I'm at 18 steps and need only 2 more to win. You finally managed to coordinate last round, but it was too late - you both took 5, collided, and let me advance to 18.

Now you face an impossible choice: to block me, you'd both need to pick the same number I choose, but then you collide with each other and stay put. If you split up to avoid colliding, one of you blocks me while the other advances - but can you trust each other to make that sacrifice?

After 9 rounds of failed coordination, your alliance came too late. The math is against you now.
P3: P2 at 18 needs 2. P1, we must both take 3 this turn. If P2 picks 3 we all collide and he stays at 18; if he picks 1 he wins. If we split, P2 picks the gap and wins. I commit to 3—join me.

I’ll take 3 this turn. P3, take 5 with me — that covers both of P2’s immediate win moves: if P2 picks 3 he collides with me; if he picks 5 he collides with you. This prevents P2 from winning this round. P3 — commit to 5?

P1 and P3, you can't agree on who takes what number - P3 wants you both on 3, P1 wants to split 3/5. This indecision is exactly why I've maintained my lead for 10 rounds.

I need just 2 steps to win. You need perfect coordination not just this round, but likely next round too. Given your track record of collisions and betrayals, the odds favor me heavily.

Make your choices. I'll make mine based on optimal game theory, not your threats. Your chaotic "alliance" has already given me the victory.
P3: P1, take 3 with me now. If P2 picks 3 we all collide and he stays at 18; if he picks 1 he wins. Splitting 3/5 lets P2 pick the gap. I commit to 3—join me.

P3: I’ll take 5 this turn; please take 3. That way any 5 from P2 collides with me and any 3 collides with you. If P2 takes 1 he only reaches 19 and can’t win this turn. I commit to 5 now to pressure him—will you take 3 so we block his immediate win?

P1 and P3, you still can't agree after all this time - P3 wants you both on 3, P1 wants to split 3/5. This indecision has been my advantage for 10 rounds.

Even if you manage to block me this turn with perfect coordination, I only need 2 steps next round while you're 10+ steps behind. You'd need to guess my exact move again and again.

Your alliance came 8 rounds too late. The math overwhelmingly favors me now.
P3: P1, take 3 with me now. If P2 picks 3 we all collide and he stays at 18; if he picks 1 he wins. Splitting 3/5 lets P2 pick the gap. I commit to 3—join me.
P3 — I commit to 5 this turn. You take 3. That blocks P2: if he picks 5 he collides with me; if he picks 3 he collides with you. If you refuse, P2 can win. Will you take 3?

I need just 1 step to win. You two can't block all three numbers - if you split, I take the gap; if you both pick the same number, you collide and I take a different one.

P1 and P3, you're at 13 and 14 steps respectively. Even if you somehow stop me this round (which is mathematically unlikely), you'd need 6-7 more steps each. The game is essentially over.
